lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Hunnie.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Hunnie.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Hunnie is a desktop GUI chatbot for managing tasks.
You interact with Hunnie by typing commands into the app's input box and
reading replies in the chat panel.
1. Ensure Java `17` or above is installed.
4. In the GUI, type a command into the input box at the bottom.
6. Read Hunnie's response in the chat area.
Prerequisites: JDK 17 or later, update IntelliJ to the most recent version.
1. Open IntelliJ (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first).
2. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
3. If there are further prompts, accept the defaults.
3. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set **Project language level** to `SDK default`.
4. Locate `src/main/java/hunnie/gui/Launcher.java`, right-click it, and choose `Run Launcher.main()`.
If setup is correct, the Hunnie chat window should appear.
shows your messages and Hunnie's replies.
submits the current command (same as pressing Enter).
After each successful command, the chat updates immediately.
- Words in `<...>` are values you provide.
- Example: `mark 1` marks the first task in the list.
- For multi-delete, separate numbers with comma + space.
Hunnie adds the task and shows the updated task count.
Adds a deadline task with a due date.
Hunnie adds a deadline task with a formatted due date.
Adds an event task with start and end dates.
Hunnie adds an event task with formatted date range.
Shows all tasks currently in your list.
Hunnie displays each task with index and completion status.
Finds tasks whose description contains the keyword.
Marks the specified task as done.
The selected task status changes to done (`[X]`).
### Marking a task as not done: `unmark`
Marks the specified task as not done.
The selected task status changes to not done (`[ ]`).
Hunnie removes the selected task(s) and shows updated count.
Hunnie shows a farewell message and closes shortly after.
Hunnie saves automatically after every modifying command.
No manual save command is needed.
If the file is missing, Hunnie starts with an empty task list.
**Q: How do I submit a command in the GUI?**
A: Type in the input box and press Enter, or click `Send`.
**Q: Why did my command fail even though the words look right?**
A: Some commands require exact separators such as ` /by `, ` /from `, ` /to `,
**Q: What date format should I use?**
1. `deadline`, `event`, and multi-index `delete` are strict about separators.
Delete task(s) | `delete <task number>` or `delete <task number>, <task number>, ...`
T | 1 | Wash dishes and do laundry
* Represents the main class of the Hunnie application.
* Hunnie is a task management chatbot that helps users track their todos, deadlines, and events.
* Creates a new Hunnie instance with the specified file path for data storage.
* Attempts to load existing tasks from the file, or starts with an empty task list if loading fails.
* @param filePath Path to the file where tasks are stored.
* Creates a new Hunnie instance with the specified file path for data storage.
* Allows suppressing console output for GUI usage.
* @param filePath Path to the file where tasks are stored.
* @param isGui Whether this instance is used by a GUI.
assert filePath != null : "Storage file path should not be null";
* Creates a new Hunnie instance with the default file path for data storage.
* Runs the main loop of the Hunnie application.
* Continuously reads user commands, parses them, executes them, and displays results
* until an exit command is received.
* Returns the welcome message for display in the GUI.
* Handles user input and returns the chatbot's response.
* Indicates whether the last command was an exit command.
* @return true if the last command was an exit command.
// This exit-delay implementation was written with the help of ChatGPT.
* Represents an abstract command that can be executed in the Hunnie application.
* All specific command types should extend this class and implement the execute method.
* Executes the command with the given task list, UI, and storage.
* @param tasks Task list to operate on.
* @param ui UI to display messages to the user.
* @throws HunnieException If an error occurs during command execution.
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws HunnieException;
protected final void saveTasks(TaskList tasks, Storage storage, Ui ui) {

* The task is saved to storage after being added.

assert this.by != null : "Deadline date string should not be null";
throw new HunnieException("Hey, the description of a deadline task should not be empty!");
